commit.message:
refactor(service-worker): remove redundant cache operation (#30977)

At this point, the response will have been cached (or scheduled to be
cached) in other code paths, so caching it again is redundant.

PR Close #30977

fix(service-worker): cache opaque responses when requests exceeds timeout threshold (#30977)

PR Close #30977

fix(service-worker): cache opaque responses in data groups with `freshness` strategy (#30977)

Previously, (presummably due to a typo) the `okToCacheOpaque` argument
of `DataGroup#cacheResponse()` was essentially never taken into account
(since opaque responses have a non-200 status code and thus `res.ok` is
always false).

This commit fixes the typo, which allows opaque responses to be cached
when `okToCacheOpaque` is true (i.e. in data groups using the
`freshness` strategy).

Fixes #30968

PR Close #30977

refactor(service-worker): make the caching behavior more explicit (#30977)

This commit doesn't change the behavior wrt caching, but it makes it
more explicit that only non-timed-out responses are cached. In case of a
timeout, `res` would be set to a programmatically created 504
`Response`, so `cacheResponse()` (which checks for `res.ok`) would not
have cached it anyway, but this makes change makes it more explicit (and
more similar to the equivalent part in [handleFetchWithFreshness()][1]).

[1]: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/2b4d5c754/packages/service-worker/worker/src/data.ts#L379-L388

PR Close #30977

test(service-worker): better simulate opaque requests (#30977)

Previously, opaque responses where handled a little differently than
other responses from the mock server. More specifically, they were not
tracked (so no assertions could be made for them) and their
[`Body` mixin][1] methods (such as `arrayBuffer()`, `json()`, `text()`)
would throw an error due to `body` being `null`.

This commit ensures opaque responses are also captured on the mock
server and also changes `Body` mixin methods to better simulate the
[spec'd behavior][2].

(These improvements will be necessary to test caching of opaque
responses in a subsequent commit.)

[1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Body
[2]: https://fetch.spec.whatwg.org/#concept-body-consume-body

PR Close #30977

test(service-worker): properly reset mock server state for each test (#30977)

PR Close #30977

test(service-worker): simplify test helpers (#30977)

PR Close #30977

test(service-worker): remove obsolete async test helpers (#30977)

Jasmine natively supports returning promises from spec functions for
quite some time now. We don't need special async helpers.

PR Close #30977

docs: couple of small UI fixes throughout some documents (#31155)

PR Close #31155

fix(ivy): incorrect namespace for root node created through ViewContainerRef (#31232)

Currently in Ivy whenever we encounter a new namespace, we set it in the global state so that all subsequent nodes are created under the same namespace. Next time a template is run the namespace will be reset back to HTML.

This breaks down if the last node that was rendered was under the SVG or MathML namespace and we create a component through `ViewContainerRef.create`, because the next template function hasn't run yet and it hasn't had the chance to update the namespace. The result is that the root node of the new component will retain the wrong namespace and may not end up rendering at all (e.g. if we're trying to show a `div` inside the SVG namespace). This issue has the potential to affect a lot of apps, because all components inserted through the router also go through `ViewContainerRef.create`.

PR Close #31232

build(docs-infra): upgrade cli command docs sources to e819d9b77 (#31307)

Updating [angular#master](https://github.com/angular/angular/tree/master) from [cli-builds#master](https://github.com/angular/cli-builds/tree/master).

##
Relevant changes in [commit range](https://github.com/angular/cli-builds/compare/01a7186bb...e819d9b77):

**Modified**
- help/generate.json

##

PR Close #31307
release: cut the v8.1.0-rc.0 release
docs: release notes for the v8.0.3 release

ci: target default pool for linux RBE executions (#31297)

PR Close #31297

docs: add "ivy" and "zone.js" to known scopes in contributing guide (#31291)

Currently the contributing guide misses entries for the `ivy` and `zone.js`
scopes. This commit adds these to the contributing guide as it is useful
for new contributors to know which scopes are supported.

PR Close #31291

style: fix code style in several files (#31295)

These files have not been formatted properly, due to issues in the
`gulp format*` tasks. See previous commits (or #31295) for more details.

PR Close #31295

build: fix formatting tasks by ignoring the `zone.js/` directory (#31295)

This was causing issues, because `zone.js` looks like a JS file (despite
it being a directory). The contents of `zone.js/` are still matched by
the globs (it is only the directory itself that is excluded).

Related to #30962.

PR Close #31295

refactor: move negative glob patterns of files to format close to their positive counterparts (#31295)

This makes it easier to identify which files in directory will be
included and which will be ignored.

PR Close #31295

build: downgrade `gulp-clang-format` to 1.0.23 (#31295)

The `gulp format*` tasks have been broken since 5eb742621. These include
the `gulp format:enforce` task, which is what runs on CI to enforce
consistent code style. Here is what (I believe) happened:

- I assume formatting was failing in 5eb742621 (moving `zone.js` into
  `angular/angular`). The reason must have been that
  [this glob pattern][1] matches `packages/zone.js/` (which is a
  directory) and passes it to `clang-format` claiming it is a file.
- I further assume that in an attempt to fix the issue,
  `gulp-clang-format` was updated to the latest version (1.0.27) in
  5eb742621.
- `gulp format:enforce` stopped complaining, so everyone thought
  formatting was fine and moved on.
- Formatting still wasn't fine, but the task completed successfully
  nevertheless :scream:
- The reason is that angular/gulp-clang-format@55b697c5c (and subsequent
  commits) changed the way the `done()` callback was called, leaving it
  to `clang-format` to call it (while previously it was also called when
  the associated stream ended).
- In the old version of `clang-format` that we are using (1.0.41), there
  is a bug (which has been fixed in angular/clang-format@4cce2c4ee):
  The callback is not called
  [unless the process exits with an error][2].

One can also see that the `gulp format:enforce` task is not completed in
`gulp lint`. Example output from [build 374722][3]:

```
yarn gulp lint
...
Starting 'format:enforce'...
Starting 'validate-commit-messages'...
...
Finished 'validate-commit-messages' after 833 ms
Starting 'tools:build'...
Finished 'tools:build' after 1.75 s
Starting 'tslint'...
Finished 'tslint' after 19 s
Done in 21.82s.
```

Notice that all tasks have a corresponding "Finished X` log, except for
`format:enforce`.

For reference:
The problem was originally reported by @ocombe on Slack ([discussion][4]).

---
This commit fixes the issue by downgrading `gulp-clang-format` to
1.0.23. The linting failures due to formatting issues will be addressed
in subsequent commits.

[1]: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/a8f3b317f/tools/gulp-tasks/format.js#L13
[2]: https://github.com/angular/clang-format/blob/b8c7df0b7/index.js#L95
[3]: https://circleci.com/gh/angular/angular/374722
[4]: https://angular-team.slack.com/archives/C042EU9T5/p1561480241191000

PR Close #31295

build: filter out changelog entries for zone.js from framework changelog (#31277)

We don't want to show entries for the `zone.js` scope in the main framework
changelog file. The zone.js changelog will be handled separately within the
`packages/zone.js` folder. (see [here](https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/31277#issuecomment-505934681))

PR Close #31277

build: allow "zone.js" as scope for commit messages (#31277)

Adds `zone.js` as valid scope for commit messages. This
is necessary because the `zone.js` repository has been
moved into the mono-repo and future changes should be
categorized properly through commit messages.

Currently the pre-commit git hook or CircleCI will fail when
`zone.js` is used as commit scope.

PR Close #31277

build(docs-infra): upgrade cli command docs sources to 01a7186bb (#31281)

Updating [angular#master](https://github.com/angular/angular/tree/master) from [cli-builds#master](https://github.com/angular/cli-builds/tree/master).

##
Relevant changes in [commit range](https://github.com/angular/cli-builds/compare/a7d4472eb...01a7186bb):

**Modified**
- help/doc.json
- help/test.json

##

PR Close #31281

fix(ivy): ngcc - don't crash if entry-points have multiple invalid dependencies (#31276)

If an entry-point has missing dependencies then it cannot be
processed and is marked as invalid. Similarly, if an entry-point
has dependencies that have been marked as invalid then that
entry-point too is invalid. In all these cases, ngcc should quietly
ignore these entry-points and continue processing what it can.

Previously, if an entry-point had more than one entry-point that
was transitively invalid then ngcc was crashing rather than
ignoring the entry-point.

PR Close #31276

fix(ivy): ngcc - do not analyze files outside the current package (#30591)

Our module resolution prefers `.js` files over `.d.ts` files because
occasionally libraries publish their typings in the same directory
structure as the compiled JS files, i.e. adjacent to each other.

The standard TS module resolution would pick up the typings
file and add that to the `ts.Program` and so they would be
ignored by our analyzers. But we need those JS files, if they
are part of the current package.

But this meant that we also bring in JS files from external
imports from outside the package, which is not desired.
This was happening for the `@fire/storage` enty-point
that was importing the `firebase/storage` path.

In this commit we solve this problem, for the case of imports
coming from a completely different package, by saying that any
file that is outside the package root directory must be an external
import and so we do not analyze those files.

This does not solve the potential problem of imports between
secondary entry-points within a package but so far that does
not appear to be a problem.

PR Close #30591

refactor(ivy): ngcc - pass `bundle` to `DecorationAnalyzer` (#30591)

Rather than passing a number of individual arguments, we can
just pass an `EntryPointBundle`, which already contains them.

This is also a precursor to using more of the properties in the bundle.

PR Close #30591

refactor(ivy): ngcc - no  need to pass `isCore` explicitly (#30591)

It is part of `EntryPointBundle` so we can just use that, which
is generally already passed around.

PR Close #30591

refactor(ivy): ngcc - expose the `entryPoint` from the `EntryPointBundle` interface (#30591)

This will allow users of the `EntryPointBundle` to use some of the `EntryPoint`
properties without us having to pass them around one by one.

PR Close #30591

refactor(ivy): ngcc - pass whole entry-point object to `makeEntryPointBundle()` (#30591)

This simplifies the interface somewhat but also allows us to make use of
other properties of the EntryPoint object in the future.

PR Close #30591

fix(ivy): ngcc - support bare array constructor param decorators (#30591)

Previously we expected the constructor parameter `decorators`
property to be an array wrapped in a function. Now we also support
an array not wrapped in a function.

PR Close #30591

issues.title: Fresh PWA does not work offline in Chrome
issues.body:
# bug report ### Affected Package @angular/pwa ### Is this a regression? I don't know. ### Description I created a new angular pwa application and deployed to Github Pages. The application does not work offline in the chrome browser. ## Minimal Reproduction https://github.com/zelite/markdown-previewer https://zelite.github.io/markdown-previewer I created the application using the angular cli, and added material components and pwa schematic. I deployed the app with the help of https://github.com/angular-schule/angular-cli-ghpages ## Exception or Error When offline, the application gets a 504 error. 

GET https://zelite.github.io/markdown-previewer/ 504 (Gateway Timeout)
The Network Tab in the developer tools shows an error requesting the following url: https://zelite.github.io/markdown-previewer/ngsw.json?ngsw-cache-bust=0.6488919669820217 ## Your Environment **Angular Version:** 

Angular CLI: 8.0.4
Node: 10.16.0
OS: win32 x64
Angular: 8.0.3
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router, service-worker

Package                           Version
-----------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect         0.800.4
@angular-devkit/build-angular     0.800.4
@angular-devkit/build-optimizer   0.800.4
@angular-devkit/build-webpack     0.800.4
@angular-devkit/core              8.0.4
@angular-devkit/schematics        8.0.4
@angular/cdk                      8.0.1
@angular/cli                      8.0.4
@angular/material                 8.0.1
@angular/pwa                      0.800.4
@ngtools/webpack                  8.0.4
@schematics/angular               8.0.4
@schematics/update                0.800.4
rxjs                              6.4.0
typescript                        3.4.5
webpack                           4.30.0
**Anything else relevant?** The application does not work offline in chrome, but it works on firefox.

issues.title: noscript content being rendered as DOM children instead of text
issues.body:
# bug report ### Affected Package Not sure. ### Is this a regression? Also not sure. ### Description When an Angular component renders a `noscript` element (use case: server rendering), the child content of the `noscript` element are appended as actual DOM element rather than just inner text. This causes axe-core to throw accessibility warnings for discernible text within the `noscript` content. See dequelabs/axe-core#1648, specifically https://github.com/dequelabs/axe-core/issues/1648#issuecomment-505118104, for more information. ## Minimal Reproduction https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-asergg?file=src%2Fapp%2Fapp.component.html I simply added the following to `app.component.html`: ```html ``` This is the result in dev tools: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7399499/60277152-a6248780-98c2-11e9-9bb1-e9e0bb21a1b4.png) If you right click on the `noscript` element, select "edit as html" and edit the text, and then click outside of the text box, the browser will correctly interpret the contents as text: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7399499/60277028-5fcf2880-98c2-11e9-875e-f8e4a565e01d.png) ## Exception or Error Not applicable. ## Your Environment **Angular Version:** 

Angular CLI: 7.3.2
Node: 10.15.3
OS: win32 x64
Angular: 7.2.5
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, elements
... forms, http, language-service, platform-browser
... platform-browser-dynamic, platform-server, router

issues.body:
When `walkTNodeTree` was refactored, the case of ICU expressions was forgotten (because it was handled in the `else` previously).
This PR fixes that to handle it like `ElementContainer`.

issues.title: bazel should support less

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Milestone for triaged issues that have not yet been scheduled for resolution.

issues.body:
#  Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- edit: -->
```
- [x] new
- [x] build
- [x] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description

Angular or Angular CLI should support less loader

### Describe the solution you'd like

Angular CLI support ng new with bazel and `less loader` before `@angular/cli@8.0.3`
but there is a bug https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/31209

The less option was removed after `8.1.0-rc.0` with https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/31234

Angular CLI should support `less` when run

`ng new --collection=@angular/bazel`

### Describe alternatives you've considered

Angular CLI should support `less` option with bazel

issues.title: Different approaches to service injection don't play well together
issues.body:
## Summary ##
Since Angular 6 there have been 2 fundamentally different ways of configuring services for injection but these 2 approaches don't interact well with one another which can result in confusing application bugs, and I don't think the implications of the 2 different approaches have been made sufficiently clear in the documentation.

## Caveat ##
I'm not really sure of the best way to categorise this issue. I think documentation improvements could help users to handle this better, but it really seems to me to be more of a design flaw in the service injection framework. From a coding perspective, I'm not really sure what could be done to improve it, but there may well be a good solution that I've been unable to think of.

Much of this problem has already been touched on by a couple of other github issues:
- https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/10170
- https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/25784

## The Current Situation ##
Prior to Angular 6, services were generally configured for injection by decorating the service's containing NgModule as follows:
```
@NgModule({
    providers: [MyService]
})
export class MyServiceModule {
```
But since Angular 6, users have been encouraged to configure services as follows instead:
```
@Injectable({
    providedIn: 'root'
})
export class MyService {
```

The new approach has 2 advantages, namely:
1.  It enables tree-shaking of unused services - since they no longer have to be included in the `providers` array of an NgModule.
2.  It ensures that only one instance of the service will ever exist - _even if the service is consumed by multiple, lazy-loaded modules_

I think it's worth noting however, that:
1.  Tree-shaking of services is only really necessary when writing a third party library. When writing an _application_ it is pretty unlikely that you would include - except perhaps by accident - a service which you weren't intending to use somewhere.
2.  Service duplication can be avoided anyway by taking appropriate care when lazy-loading modules - although the new approach _is_ safer in this respect.

The new approach also has one very important implication though, which I don't think is made sufficiently clear in the documentation, and which in turn can lead to confusing dependency issues when both approaches are used within the same application (or across different libraries which are consumed by that application):

## Service "Ownership" ##
If `MyService` is configured for injection using the `@NgModule` `providers` decoration, the service can rightly be considered to "belong" to that NgModule. It is also therefore that module's responsibility to make sure that it imports any other NgModules which provide services that `MyService` depends on.

If `MyService` is configured using the `@Injectable`, `providedIn: 'root'` syntax though, the service no longer really "belongs" anywhere. It might be co-located with a particular NgModule on the file system, but it has no relationship to it - it doesn't know about the module, and the module doesn't know about the service. This may not be immediately obvious to developers.

Because there is no longer an "owning" NgModule, the `MyService` class will now just be bundled with whatever consumes it, and it is then the _consumer's_ responsibility to ensure that the service's dependencies - i.e. any services which are injected into it - are available. This is fine if all _those_ services have also been configured with `providedIn: 'root'` (and also all of _their_ dependencies, etc.). It becomes more complicated though, in a scenario where interdependencies exist between services that have been configured in different ways - as can easily happen when using third party libraries, or even when consuming built-in Angular services that have been configured via the old-style `providers` array.

## Problem Example ###
Consider the following scenario:

1.  `MyComponent` is in `MyComponentModule` and consumes `MyService` which has been decorated with `providedIn: 'root'`. `MyService` is "in" (but not really - it is just co-located with) `MyServiceModule`.
2.  `MyService` consumes `ThirdPartyService` _which hasn't been similarly decorated_. Instead, `ThirdPartyService` has been provided via the `providers` array in `ThirdPartyServiceModule`.
3. `MyServiceModule` imports `ThirdPartyServiceModule`, but as it turns out this is incidental, because _`MyService` doesn't really belong to `MyServiceModule`_

The code fails at run time, when it attempts to instantiate `MyService` for injection into `MyComponent` with:
```
NullInjectorError: No provider for ThirdPartyService!
```

This is because `MyComponentModule` has not imported `ThirdPartyServiceModule`, but this is not very obvious to the developer. It doesn't seem very logical (to me anyway) that `MyComponentModule` should have to care about `MyService`'s dependencies (or perhaps even its dependencies' dependencies), just because of the different ways in which these services have been configured.

As I say, I don't really know what the best way is to fix this - apart from perhaps making the implications of all this a little clearer in the documentation. The cat is now somewhat out of the bag regarding the (now not-so-)new `providedIn: 'root'` syntax and at the moment I can't think of a way to make these 2 different approaches play nicely with each other.

milestone.description: Milestone for triaged issues that have not yet been scheduled for resolution.

issues.body:
## PR Checklist
Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements:

- [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit
- [ ] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [x] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)


## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

<!-- Please check the one that applies to this PR using "x". -->

- [ ] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [x] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:


## What is the current behavior?
<!-- Please describe the current behavior that you are modifying, or link to a relevant issue. -->

There were some typos and incorrect examples.

Issue Number: N/A


## What is the new behavior?


## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No


<!-- If this PR contains a breaking change, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications below. -->


## Other information

issues.title: Language service "component not in module" error when using `require.context`
issues.body:
# bug report ### Affected Package @angular/language-service ### Is this a regression? No ### Description I use dynamic importing of components (require.context) to import them into angular modules. Angular language service can't detect that so it issues me the `Component 'x' is not included in a module and will not be available inside a template. Consider adding it to a NgModule declaration` error on all of my components. I know that angular can't do much here to detect those usages, so can I at least disable this error in the language service? ## Your Environment **Angular Version:** 
Angular CLI: 7.3.2
Node: 12.4.0
OS: win32 x64
Angular:
...

------------------------------------------------------

No ### Description `ng build --aot` reports an error in a html template, but does not state in which template file ## Minimal Reproduction I have created the sample project [here](https://github.com/pakopa/ng-build-issue-20190626/tree/127ec9aeedbdcdab5762d4f641aa5ee173491a91) clone and run `ng bulid --aot` ## Exception or Error Expected output when running `ng bulid --aot` 

...
chunk {styles} styles.js, styles.js.map (styles) 16.3 kB [initial] [rendered]

ERROR in : 'test-component' is not a known element:
1. If 'test-component' is an Angular component, then verify that it is part of this module.
2. If 'test-component' is a Web Component then add 'CUSTOM_ELEMENTS_SCHEMA' to the '@NgModule.schemas' of this component to suppress this message. ("

")

issues.title: Add support for indexing templates

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Milestone for triaged issues that have not yet been scheduled for resolution.

issues.body:
@alxhub and I recently discussed how best to implement indexing templates in the [`Ngtsc` indexing module](./packages/compiler-cli/src/ngtsc/indexer). I'm dumping the key points of that discussion here for future reference and discussion.

#  feature request

### Relevant Package

For @angular/compiler-cli, `Ngtsc` indexer module.

### Description

The compiler's indexing module does not currently support indexing HTML elements in templates. We want to add support for that. Initially, the scope of this was

- Record element selectors used in the template
- Record used directives in the template

such that an indexer could link an element selector to the directive it references, if any. This approach is quite limiting, however, because directive selectors can match on many things beside element selectors, including matching on attributes and implicitly matching on the absence of an attribute. A better approach is

- Record element selectors used in the template
  - each selector record also includes a record of attributes on the element
  - each selector record also includes a record of used directives on the element

To consider the usefulness of this, consider a template like `<my-comp applied-dir>` that uses the directives `MyComp`, `AppliedDir`, and an implicitly loaded directive `ImplicitDir`. The compiler's indexer module will index the template and record an element identifier that looks something like

```typescript
{
  name: 'my-comp',
  span: ...,
  attributes: [ { name: 'applied-dir', span: ... } ],
  usedDirectives: [ MyComp, AppliedDir, ImplicitDir ],
}
```

A source code indexer implementation can then use this information to generate useful references, like xreferencing `my-comp` to the `MyComp` class declaration, `applied-dir` to the `AppliedDir` class declaration, and adding an implicit reference of all three used directives on `my-comp`.

### Alternatives

- Do not record attributes separately; pass the entire element tag source code as the element identifier name instead.
  - __advantages__: less work for the compiler's indexing module.
  - __disadvantages__: an indexer implementation now has to write an HTML parser to discern attributes on the element.
- Perform the linking of attributes to the directives that match it in the compiler.
  - __advantages__: less work for an indexer implementation
  - __disadvantages__: directives are applied to an element, not an attribute, so such an implementation would be needlessly complicated. Furthermore, it is not necessarily the job of the compiler's semantic analysis API to make decisions about what spans of text reference one another, especially in ambiguous cases like the one presented here - that should be on the indexer implementation.

issues.title: fix(ivy): ngtsc - NgtscCompilerHost should cope with directories that

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Milestone for triaged issues that have not yet been scheduled for resolution.

issues.body:
look like files

The TS compiler is likely to test paths with extensions and try to
load them as files. Therefore `fileExists()` and methods that rely
on it need to be able to distinguish between real files and directories
that have paths that look like files.

This came up as a bug in ngcc when trying to process `ngx-virtual-scroller`,
which relies upon a library called `@tweenjs/tween.js`.

issues.title: Add info about updating libraries to static query migration guide

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Milestone for triaged issues that have not yet been scheduled for resolution.

issues.body:
Recent conversations with GDEs have brought up that it's not clear how libraries should handle adding the new static flag for v8 compatibility. [This thread](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/30654#issuecomment-495642339) has the relevant info about how v7 apps will continue to work with v8 libs that have the static flags (so our recommendation for libs is to update to add the flags). 

Since this thread is difficult to find, we should add the info to the FAQ in the migration guide here:

http://angular.io/guide/static-query-migration

# bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/.... Router ### Is this a regression? Dunno Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: .... ### Description A clear and concise description of the problem... I have a following routing configuration: [ { path: 'parent', children: [ { path: ':parentId', children: [ { path: 'child1', loadChildren: () => import(...), }, { path: 'child2', loadChildren: () => import(...), } ] } ], { path: '**', component: NotFoundPageComponent }, ] When I am on child1 and trying to navigate to child2, the wildcard route is activated instead of navigating to child2. I think this is caused by the fact that module is being loaded lazy. When I comment the wildcard statement, routing works fine. ## Minimal Reproduction https://stackblitz.com/... ## Exception or Error

# bug report ### Affected Package @angular/compiler-cli ### Is this a regression? No ### Description If you execute `npm run build ngcc-test-library && npm run build ngcc-test-app --prod` command on reproduction demo repository, you can see the error I wrote below. And you can also find that `NgccTestSecondaryModule` which is imported by `NgccTestLibraryModule` was not processed by Ngcc. webpack                            4.30.0
**Anything else relevant?**

issues.title: fix(docs-infra): fix api list search color and styles

milestone.title: needsTriage
milestone.description: Milestone for all issues that haven't been triaged yet

issues.body:
Fixes #31265

Addressed accessibility color issue (the styles were not originally applying so I removed them so it looks as intended.

I also cleaned up some of the layout styles and mobile view of the api list filter/search elements.

<hr>

- [ ] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)

## PR Type

- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:


## What is the current behavior?
